abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Institutional Reform
            Project in Bolivia were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome was high,
            the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory.
            Lessons learned included: a political economic analysis of
            reforms was not undertaken as part of the project's
            design, affecting project implementation. The project
            strategy relied squarely on the strong leadership role of
            personalities, rather than placing the project within an
            institutionally strong agency. This strategy collapsed with
            the change of government. Project implementation improved
            dramatically when incentives for reform were identified and
            the main stakeholders of reforms took the driver's
            seat. Fiscal constraints created incentives to improve
            revenue collection, and the Ministry of Finance strongly
            supported reforms in collection agencies and control of the
            payroll. The Ministry of Finance took the leadership of the
            project and promoted reforms in Tax and Customs Agencies, as
            well on civil service wage bill management. Positive results
            in Civil Service Reform should be expanded across all levels
            of governments and enhanced with the implementation of
            policies for a merit-based promotion system and a new
            structure of salaries. Mechanisms to promote and facilitate
            access of indigenous people to the Civil Service-a very
            important policy in the Government agenda can be
            strengthened if the Civil Service reform continues in this
            direction. Strong analytical work could have provided
            information about alternatives for reform and reduced the
            expectations generated by the project's ambitious
            design. Analytical work performed during project
            implementation demonstrated that the Financial
            Administration and Control System (SAFCO) legal framework
            needed to be improved due to weak regulations and the
            prevalence of informal practices in the budget process. The
            studies also showed that Integrated Public Financial
            Management System (SIGMA) has important weaknesses. Had this
            information been available earlier, a more adequate strategy
            to introduce a results-based management reform could have
            been designed for the project. Strengthening the regulatory
            framework and information technology systems should be
            guaranteed before introducing a results-based management system.

repnme.cdata!:
Bolivia - Institutional Reform Project :
            proposed amendment

abstracts.cdata!:
The amendment will restructure the
            Project's design and make its comprehensive public
            sector reform approach more consistent with the
            government's strategy and country's possibilities
            for reform. Despite the difficult political and social
            situation in Bolivia, the Government maintains its
            commitment to advance in some of the reform areas covered by
            the project. For this purpose the government requests: (1)
            the transfer of the Project's Technical Unit from the
            Ministry of Sustainable Development to the Ministry of
            Finance; (2) cancellation of the components pertaining to
            Part A - Performance-oriented Management and Evaluation of
            Public Sector Organizations and Part B - Combating
            Corruption; (3) correction of 1998 baseline and
            corresponding figures of Performance Benchmarks No. 3 and
            No. 4 for the period 2000-2004; and (4) reallocation of
            amounts and redistribution of financial resources
            corresponding to category 3 salaries, as well as
            cancellation of SDR 1,204,424 (US1.73 million equivalent) of
            the Development Credit Agreement and the co-financing grant
            agreements (related trust funds).

5084550.trustfund:

            PROJECT (DANISH GRANT),TF052116-PHRD-BOLIVIA: INSTITUTIONAL
            REFORM PROJECT,TF023309-BOLIVIA INSTITUTIONAL REFORM PROJECT,TF039667-BOLIVIA - INSTITUTIONAL REFORM PROJECT,TF023885-SWEDISH GRANT FOR THE
            INSTITUTIONAL REFORM PROJECT IN BOLIVIA

abstracts.cdata!:
The Institutional Reform Project, the
            first phase of the Public Sector Modernization Project seeks
            to improve the effectiveness, efficiency, and transparency
            of the Bolivian administration in order to strengthen the
            country's ability to implement its economic and social
            development programs and thus combat poverty. There are five
            project components. The first, the performance evaluation
            component, adjusts the regulatory framework, designs and
            launches management and evaluation systems, and builds the
            capacity of the rector agencies. The second component,
            builds national integrity by combating corruption through
            reforming the legal framework, developing prevention
            policies and mechanisms, setting up an ombudsman's
            office, streamlining bureaucratic procedures, reforming the
            procurement process, and increasing social communication,
            particularly a massive citizen education program. The civil
            service component implements the legal framework, develops
            personnel systems, and builds the capacity of the rector
            institutions. The fourth component, organizational reform,
            restructures the pilot agencies, supports professional cadre
            positions in the ministries, and reforms the budget. The
            fifth component, reform management, funds the entity serving
            as the project coordination unit.
